awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: FMitF: Track II: Enhancing the Neural Network Verification (NNV) Tool for Industrial Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The safety and reliability of systems incorporating machine-learning components are significant challenges. New techniques are crucial to enable rigorous analysis before deploying these data-driven machine-learning components for tasks ranging from sensing and perception to planning and control in safety-critical domains, such as aerospace and automotive systems. This project enhances the Neural Network Verification (NNV) software tool for deep neural networks and learning-enabled autonomous systems to enable industrial usage through engagement with industry partners in aerospace, automotive, and design automation. The project's novelty is the development of new verification techniques for neural networks that process time-series data and new ways to specify temporal behaviors. The project's impact is developing and applying rigorous analysis methods, as well as helping transition these methods to industry, which may eventually be used in the engineering-assurance and certification processes of real-world learning-enabled systems.

This project will develop new neural-network verification methods for time-series data and architectures, then implement these in the NNV software tool, and evaluate them on challenging benchmarks and case studies from industry. The new time-series analysis techniques combine the relaxed star reachability approach with counterexample-guided abstraction refinement (CEGAR) methods to improve verification scalability while maintaining precision. Trace-based properties for these time-series problems will be specified in formalisms such as metric temporal logic (MTL) and signal temporal logic (STL), as well as extensions of these logics. NNV will also be improved for usability and documentation, as well as evaluated for these improvements, in part by continuing to use it within courses taught by the researchers, as well as collaborating with industry partners. Industrial-scale benchmarks and case studies developed with industry partners will strengthen engagement of the broader formal-methods and machine-learning research communities through events such as the Neural Network Verification Competition (VNN-COMP) and the Hybrid Systems Verification (ARCH-COMP) category on Artificial Intelligence and Neural Network Control Systems (AINNCS).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Deploying data-driven machine learning components, such as neural networks, within cyber-physical systems (CPS) for tasks ranging from sensing and perception to planning and control is an emerging interest in the automotive industry. However, the reliability and safety of ML components in the physical world raise significant concerns about data-driven methods, as well as how to incorporate them into the traditional verification and validation (V\&V) processes needed for such safety-critical systems. Most research in the neural network verification domain has focused on computer vision tasks. In contrast, our ongoing industrial collaborations indicate many tasks will involve other forms of sensory data, particularly over time-series data, especially in tasks for prognostics and control. This project proposes to continue collaborations with our industrial partner, Toyota, to develop novel verification approaches and neural network verification methods for time-series data, all to be implemented within our Neural Network Verification (NNV) software tool. Our fundamental research results in two publications in top-tier venues in formal methods and cyber-physical systems. The first research, Verification of Recurrent Neural Networks with Star Reachability, was published at the  26th ACM International Conference on Hybrid Systems: Computation and Control (HSCC 2023), in which we developed a star reachability method to verify therobustness of recurrent neural networks (RNNs) for use in safety-critical applications. Compared to state-of-the-art methods, our exact verification method is 10x faster, while the overapproximation method is 100x to 5000x faster. The second research, NNV2.0-The Neural Network Verification Tool, was published at the 35th International Conference on Computer-Aided Verification. In this research, we have added new features and verification approaches for new deep neural network models, such as RNNs, LSTM, GRU, neural ODEs, etc., for industrial and academic users. In addition to fundamental research, the project will also support the transition of advanced verification techniques to practice by improving documentation, benchmarks, evaluation, and engagement with the broader community through initiatives such as the Neural Network Verification Competition (VNN-COMP) and the Hybrid Systems Verification Competition (ARCH-COMP) category on Artificial Intelligence and Neural Network Control Systems (AINNCS). We have given two tutorials on Neural Network and Autonomous Cyber-Physical Systems Formal Verification for Trustworthy AI and Safe Autonomy for industrial engineers and researchers at Embedded Systems Week 2023 and the International Automated Vehicle Validation Conference 2023. 


Last Modified: 06/04/2024
Modified by: Dung Tran
